title: Chinese money lender steals wheels from car and leaves an angry public message
title_page: Chinese money lender steals wheels from car and leaves an angry public message | Daily Mail Online
text:
A woman had three wheels removed from a car in central China after the owner, who owed her money, failed to show up.
Pictures of the abandoned vehicle raised on some bricks were taken yesterday morning next to a hotel in Weinan city, Shaanxi Province.
The owner of the green Toyota, allegedly owes the woman name Ms Zhou, 100,000 Yuan (£10,712), reports the People's Daily Online.
Angry: Car vandalized with a sign that reads'owner of the car doesn't pay debt' pictured yesterday in China
Payback: Woman was hoping the person who owed her money would eventually return to their car, but didn't
As well as having the wheels removed, Ms Zhou placed a massive sign on the car that read: 'Owner of the car doesn't pay debt.'
Staff at the hotel said the car had been left parked on the sidewalk of Cangcheng Road since January 20, and the wheels were removed four days ago.
Even after the car was vandalised, the owner still did not show up.
The two were heard having a dispute over money a few days before the wheels were taken off.
According to the report, traffic police arrived at the scene, but they did not do anything about the vehicle and are yet to locate the owner of the car.
High price: The owner of the green Toyota, allegedly owes the woman name Ms Zhou, 100,000 Yuan (£10,712)
Ms Zhao spoke to local reporters and said: 'I found the car was parked by the road and kept an eye on it for four days in order to find the owner. However, that person never turned up.
'I had no choice but to take off the wheels and hope this could force the owner to appear.
However, four days after the parts were taken off, still no one showed up. And I had to hire people to look after the car.'
A police officer handing the case said Ms Zhao admitted her son had removed the wheels from the car because of money disputes.
The police urged both parties to find a judicial solution as spoon a s possible.
